challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: Any registrar-appointed challenger or any elector in the municipality may challenge a voter in that municipality.
Challenges are permitted at the polling place on Election Day. Challenges may not be made "indiscriminately," and must be made under oath.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

subtopics.fact: Only identity, residence and an accusation that the voter has been disenfranchised for a felony conviction are acceptable reasons for a challenge.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?

subtopics.fact: A challenger must know, suspect, or reasonably believe that the challenged voter is not eligible to vote.
subtopics.subtopic: Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact: A challenged voter must defend their eligibility to the poll worker called the "moderator." The moderator makes a decision, and if the moderator overturns the challenge, the voter may vote. If not, the voter may request and vote a "challenged ballot."
subtopics.subtopic: How does a voter defend their eligibility to vote if they are challenged?

subtopics.fact: ID will be requested of all voters. However, it is only required of first-time voters who did not register in person with a government official, and who have not been verified by their drivers' license number, social security number, or copy of their ID. (Other voters can sign a form at the polling place instead of showing ID.)
subtopics.subtopic: Who must show ID to vote?

subtopics.fact:
• * Current, valid photo ID showing the voter's name and address
  • * Copy of a current utility bill, bank statement, government check, paycheck, or other government document that shows the voter's name and address

No. A voter who is required to show ID who does not provide ID must vote provisionally. They may then be required to take additional steps to get their ballot to count. Provisional voting is only offered in elections with federal offices on the ballot.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?
Is a student ID an acceptable form of identification?

citations: Conversation with Bernard Liu, Staff Attorney in the Elections Division of the Secretary of State's Office, on 11/10/2011
subtopics.subtopic: Does the ID have to show the address at which the voter is registered to vote?

subtopics.fact: No, all elections have the same ID requirements.
